wikipedia_page.main: Jean Esther Floud  (née McDonald; 3 November 1915 – 28 March 2013) was a prominent educational sociologist and later an academic. She was Principal of Newnham College, Cambridge, from 1972 to 1983.

response: The Robbins Report of 1963 advocated substantial expansion of higher education in the United Kingdom, taking the line, often called now the "Robbins principle", that demand from those suitably qualified should drive its development. There was background at the LSE for the view taken, in work of Richard Layard and Claus Moser, and it drew also on recent ideas of Jean Floud and A. H. Halsey. Robbins became the first Chancellor of the new University of Stirling in 1968. He also advocated major government support for the arts, as well as universities.
*Jean Floud (1915–2013), sociologist and academic, was born there.Robert Skidelsky, "Jean Floud obituary", The Guardian, 3 April 2013.
* Peter Floud (1911–1960), civil servant, husband of Jean Floud
* Jean Floud (née MacDonald) (1915–2013), sociologist and principal of Newnham College

response: *Jean Floud, sociologist, Nuffield College Oxford. Principal of Newnham College, Cambridge, declined a peerage (in 1978).
*Jean Floud, 97, British educational sociologist, Principal of Newnham College, Cambridge (1972–1983).Jean Floud obituary
